comments.commentBody:
I went to college in the 1960's. I went to the University of Chicago for 3 years and then transferred to UCLA for my senior year, and thus graduated from UCLA.

Transferring from Chicago to UCLA (at that time, not now) was almost like tranferring to a summer camp. It was almost trivially easy.

However, when I went to look for a job, no one had ever heard of the University of Chicago, but they were totally impressed that I had graduated from UCLA because UCLA had a really good basketball team at the time. This helped me get a higher paying job.

This is just an anecdote, but I think that going to an elite school that is not well known rather than a more well known but less elite one only helps in a small number of cases. In general, I think that, as far as making money goes, a more well known school helps more.

This is true even of Ivy league schools. I live on the West coast, and here the only schools that even very educated people know are Ivies are Harvard, Yale, and Princeton. Most have heard of Columbia and Brown, but don't know that they are Ivies. Many people may have heard of Penn, Dartmouth, or Cornell but would have no idea that they were elite. In fact, they would not be able to differentiate the University of Pennsylvania from Penn State, and if they did, they would think Penn State was the better because it had a better football team.

#38 has it right - every child needs a "good parent"; to be protected and to have someone to belong to and to feel secure and develop well.  No matter the program or placement, a vetted and well trained advocate/mentor assigned to the child who can spend at least 5 hours ( 10+ would be better ) a week providing protection ( child focused )  guidance, support, love, advice and steadiness as the child grows their identity will have the best chance of succeeding.  Big Sisters / Big Brothers takes this approach but does not ensure sufficient weeky time is spent with the child.

Let the children decide. On the whole, they know what is best for them better than anyone else. I did when I was 11 and chose to hide all signs of abuse so as not to be placed into foster care, and I do not regret it.

With the anger we are seeing around the country from Republican governors and legislatures toward government employees, it's going to get harder and harder to find the kind of educated and dedicated staff that is needed for programs like these.  In the name of fiscal responsibility, those states would rather spend more on the services that can be outsourced to private for-profit corporations than save money on more effective but unprofitable methodologies.

I applaud efforts to work with at-risk youth and their families so that these children have a better chance at success. However, I agree with previous comments on the comparison with such a program with the workings of a broken child welfare system that places parents rights over childrens rights.

The reason many children are placed in multiple homes is, in many cases, due to parents who fail their children over and over again while the court system refuses to grant permanency to these children. When children are young, it is nearly impossible to terminate rights, in spite of physical or emotional abuse, drug and alcohol use, etc. A parent receives chance after chance, which extends a child's time in limbo in the system. Children wind up in residential treatment centers for many reasons, including mental health issues, age, lack of appropriate foster care, and other complex reasons that this article only touches briefly on. If permanency, safety and positive outcome were stressed early on by the courts, then more children would be in stable homes years before the need to be placed in a residential treatment center.

By all means, provide services to parents when this is deemed a workable solution. However if youth either remain in care for more than two years, or if they are returned to care again and again, then all bets should be off. Someone needs to advocate for the children in these situations and recognize that returning them to a relative is wonderful if they can do it, but not always a viable solution.

This program has a very high success rate. This makes me wonder: Are applicants and their families screened prior to participating? I would hope so. And, if this is the case, then the high success rate only means that the families chosen for the in-house services were not being served correctly in the first place under our broken child welfare system.

I'm sorry, this shirt is both clever and funny. I can see why some people might not get it.  But like it says in the post, any real Mets fan has enough of a relationship with suffering to appreciate the humor.

It was not clear to me from this article whether this program is directed at children who were being removed from the home because of parental abuse/neglect of the child or the child's delinquent behavior. Although these populations are definitely overlapping, they are not the same. The specific examples offered all seem to be related to older children who would be placed because of their own behavior, but the article seems at times to be referring to children who would have been placed in foster care because of parental abuse and neglect.

I was pleased to see that the intensive services are actually quite intensive. However, if these services are going to be used for children who have been abused and neglected I would worry that children would remain in danger while services are being implemented. That being said, there is a shortage of good foster parents, and some children may be better off with parents who are receiving intensive services than with less supervised foster parents. As a pediatrician, I have met foster parents who are excellent, horrible, and everywhere in between.

Far more resources need to be devoted to the care of all of these vulnerable children.

Haven't we been down this road before? The "depraved on accounta I'm deprived" model (as they say in 'West Side Story') has been alternating with the "parent-ectomy" model in a pendulum swing for decades. First the bureaucrats work to "keep kids in the home," especially if the race card has been played, until a ghastly case of abuse by a parent on their umpteenth "try" makes headlines and brings public disgust to a boil. Then, under political pressure from the other side, they yank kids (yes, especially minority kids) too readily, and send them into limbo with foster parents who seem as bad as the bio moms. Of the two extremes, the "family unification" model seems the most delusional in cases of genuine abuse (as opposed to neglect). What "extensive array of in-home support services" can significantly alter the behavior of a parent who is fundamentally cruel, pathologically selfish, or lost to addiction? What "services" can transform a family life built on brutality, degradation, or sexual exploitation? The social work model can accomplish some good, some of the time...but God help children when we refuse to admit the existence of evil. Do I sound cynical? Must be because I just served on a grand jury. People who willfully and repeatedly harm children, whether actively through abuse or passively through neglect, need more than "intensive services." No team of taxpayer-funded housekeepers, therapists, tutors, nutritionists and what-all can change the human heart or imbue a sense of personal responsibility. If those are what's missing, perhaps a child has a better chance even on the rough seas of foster care.

Welcome to the beginning of WW3, courtesy of our banking/corporate overlords.  Freedom and rights!? Pleeeease, this is big boy stuff. Global corporatocracy will never allow the people in that region to decide their own fate, or this one for that matter.

Poster #607 : It is no more correct to fault a person who has acquired some savings after an honest life of work  which included charitable giving with being an "evil" rich person  while there are still millions who live somewhere in poverty than it is to fault a healthy  person  for being health  while others are suffering from  cancer or illnesses. All people of wealth did not "steal" their earnings!  There are some people who are born gorgeous while others are born rather ugly.  So much of where we are born and how we look and what we inherit has nothing to do with "justice."  Life is just not " fair."    That is why "envy" was  concerned a sin. Envy often leads to hatred.  Hatred   can lead to destruction  and death.  And  giving into  the idea that one can "equalize"  all of life's  inequities  can led to far more injustice than the original inequity which life had  throw  one's  way.
Something NEEDS to be done about this and it needs to happen soon. Qaddafi’s actions are outrageously inhuman and demand an immediate and forceful international response.
Unarmed citizens there, but we have our 2nd Amendmant, Allah be praised.

Where is John Paul Jones when we need him.  Didn't he deal with the Barbary Pirates? Capture all the pirates.  Try them on board ship.  Then hang them.  We need a professor of pirate studies at the Naval War College?

Powerless Hawaiians have had more influence over International Affairs than these un-United Nations actors...
I've had to listen to and/or read about these UN lies since 1948. For Christchurch sakes, it's time to get REAL!

Our government should announce and implement a policy of trial by US Navy Captain's hearing on board ship, and immediate execution upon conviction, of any pirate captured while interfering with any US flagged vessel.  Kill a couple of hundred and all pirate activity would stop.

The world does not need another Jonestown massacre on a national scale involving this time innocent Libyans at the hands of Moammar Qaddafi. In  a speech that could have been written by the diabolic Rev. Jim Jones, Qaddafi exposed just how dangerously deluded he has been and the evil he intends. His evil intentions to sacrifice the Libyan people to maintain his grip on power are apparent. The world ought to take him at his word and stop him before it's too late. Have we learned nothing since Guyana,1978? And what is a United Nations for if not to stop tragedies like the one we see unfolding before our eyes in Libya?

Re: #20
Manic Drummer
Madison, WI

"One desperate man has to resort to murder to stay in power. He never deserved to be a leader."

We're talking about Qaddafi here now Manic Drummer, not about Gov. Scott Walker, who is threatening public employees with his version of Kent State. Please stay on topic.

Killing pirates cuts way down on repeat offenses. Making it clear that America will concede little in negotiation and gladly kill pirates will hopefully drive them away from our citizens and shipping.

Nations should also take note of end of the Golden Age of Piracy in the 1700s; merchant ships began carrying guns.

Sorry for them, but how is sailing off the coast of Somalia any different then flying to Mogadishu and walking outside the airport, flashing a big roll of bills, and asking the nearest driver to take you for a ride around the city?

Regardless of the details of this tragic outcome, it is hard to believe that civilized nations with their mighty navies are not able to wipe out the pirates and their Somalia bases.

What are we paying for in our taxes to build and maintain a huge flotilla of naval ships if we are not using them to protect us?

Are there some restrictions put on them to prevent them to fight (i.e., KILL) the pirates efficiently?

Of course, for small boats to enter these infested waters in definitely not the smartest thing to do.

Speculations about the behavior of the pirates is a complete nonsense, #25, although we were surely NOT told the entire story.

The New York Times fails to mention the fact that these Americans were missionaries who were distributing a boat full of Bibles.  This may not be related to their unfortunate fates but it is curious that the fact is omitted by the New York Times and not other news services.
friendly fire?  i seriously doubted the pirates killed the american hostages.

Sounds like another government lie.   I bet anything that our guys got trigger-happy, stormed the boat, and the pirates killed the hostages in retaliation.   Can the government ever tell the truth about anything?
What are Americans doing in Libya anyway?  Gaddafi bombed Pan Am 103.

In a flash of beautiful premonition I see Quadaffi in a orange jumpsuit buried in legal documents up to his face in a very boring grey meeting room somewhere within an hour drive from the Hague. He ends his life suffering under the total boredom that will surround him when his last years are spent shuffling from court room to court room under the polite and professional escort of dutch security officers. "this way sir". "Stand away from the door sir". "Here is another legal brief for your perusal sir". A fitting end for any mass murderer. And all of us at home, heating up leftovers in the microwave watching his perp walk for the 10 seconds his segment lasts and then on to the next news story. I long for this prediction to hold true. Please!
